awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: Computational Joinery
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of the project is to develop the theory, techniques, and mechanical designs needed for robots to rapidly build large, rigid structures from blocks that geometrically interlock, without the need for fasteners, cement, or glue. The work is motivated by the desire to quickly assemble structurally strong buildings, furniture, and devices, in such a way that the structure may later be disassembled and the parts re-used. Fabricating in parts presents many advantages: for instance, individual components may be fabricated efficiently, packed for storage and transport, repaired or replaced as needed, and design changes can be made readily in response to changing customer needs. Design of smooth surface finishes allows applications such as modular furniture and packaging of delicate parts for shipping, and embedding mechanical or electrical components will allow rapid construction of robots and other devices.

The problem to be studied is how structures may be designed to rigidly interlock, using cycles of geometric constraints imposed by blocks to reinforce, support, and immobilize other blocks. Goals for the project include: 1) the design of joint geometries that allow a connection process that is robust to assembly and fabrication errors; 2) mechanical block designs that allow incremental construction of interlocked structures; and 3) layout algorithms that tailor assembly sequences to allow construction of desired shapes. Methods and approaches include mechanical design, development of layout algorithms, and analysis of assembly processes to ensure structural stability during construction. Experimental work includes robot assembly to validate the approach for complex structures involving hundreds of blocks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to study the problem of how to construct large structures using blocks that are interlocked by the geometries of the joints rather than using glues, such as cements. The study focused on the design of the joints, the assembly strategies, and the implementation of the automated assembly with robots. A main focus of the work at the University at Albany was to study whether the computational methods can be used to aid the design of the mechanisms.

On the technical side, the Albany side collaborated with the lead team at Dartmouth to analyze and bound the errors that exist in the non-perfect assemblies. The collaborating team at Dartmouth explored using underwater assembly while the research team at UAlbany also explored the aspect of automated design for insertion-based joints. The analysis and the simulation show advantages, and the work is currently under review.

The project also started to explore how simulation can be integrated into the design process to validate and redesign suitable joineries. The team focused on the simulation of underwater joineries and block simulation, integrated the Lattice Boltzmann method with bullet physics, and simulated how blocks sink underwater.

The broader impact of this project was primarily educational, training the next generation of scientists and leaders. The project was the main source of support for one graduate student. The developed motion teaching platform has been deployed for initial round of testing to gather feedback from users to evaluate different lesson plans.


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Gary J Saulnier
